awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Nature of the Pre-chemistry Ensemble in Protein Kinases
awd_abstract_narration:
Kinases are biological molecules that modify the rate of specific chemical reactions in cells. They and the products of these chemical reactions represent central hubs in the intracellular signaling networks in all domains of life. In addition to sub-cellular localization and temporal expression, the efficiencies of particular kinases towards specific molecular products is key in targeting input signals towards distinct physiological outputs. The goal of this project is to understand the nature of this regulation with sufficient resolution in space and time to provide the means to perturb and ultimately design signaling networks that drive specific input signals towards defined cellular responses. This project will also provide a fertile training ground for a graduate student and several undergraduate researchers in a wide variety of skills that range from computational methodology, experimental NMR and enzyme biochemistry. The undergraduates will be drawn from the pool of students who transfer from one of the seven community colleges that are part of the City University of New York (CUNY) into the City College of New York (CCNY) with a goal of encouraging them to pursue higher education in the STEM disciplines. It is notable that the graduate student who is expected on this project was formerly a transfer student who has chosen to pursue his PhD degree in Biochemistry.  

The transfer of a phosphate group from adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to specific serine, threonine or tyrosine residues of substrate proteins represents a central mechanism of signal transduction within cells and plays a critical role in almost all physiological processes. This transfer is enabled by biocatalysts known as protein kinases and involves the formation of a pre-chemistry complex between the kinase, the substrate and ATP. Recent studies suggest that the nature of the structural dynamics of the catalytic elements of the kinase and the phospho-acceptor region of the substrate in the context of this pre-chemistry complex determines the efficiency of the phospho-transfer reaction and contributes to its variability between specific kinase/substrate pairs. These variations in phosphorylation efficiency between kinase/substrate pairs is necessary to maintain the finely tuned network of numerous phosphorylation based signaling events occurring simultaneously in the cell. An understanding of these differences in efficiency requires the characterization in atomic detail of the conformational state/states that comprise the pre-chemistry complex. This project, using a combination of cutting-edge computational approaches, solution-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) methods and biochemical assays, aims to characterize the conformational states that define the pre-chemistry complex towards the goal of addressing the following question: what determines the efficiency of phosphorylation within a kinase-substrate-ATP pre-chemistry complex? The model system chosen for this project involves the mitogen-activated protein kinase ERK2 and peptides derived from its natural substrate, the transcription factor Elk-1, that are phosphorylated with differing efficiencies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

We developed a novel approach that characterizes the residue-specific structural environment and variations therein to ascertain regions of variability within ensembles of folded proteins. This approach, we term EVA (Environment Variability Analysis), offers several advantages over conventional measures of variability. First, to define variability within an ensemble, EVA relies on an estimation of the per-residue local environment within each constituent structure and therefore does not require the superimposition of individual structures. The latter process becomes non-trivial with increasing size and/or in the presence of substantial conformational variability. Second, EVA provides the ability to distinguish regions that display significant diversity in local contacts from those with intrinsic variability, e.g. termini or solvent-exposed loops, that make few contacts with the structured core. This distinction is difficult when relying on conventional measures of variability. Third, EVA allows smaller changes, that are potentially relevant for function, to be highlighted through the removal of the obscuring effects of larger ones using a robust iterative procedure. Fourth, since EVA relies on the definition of a residue-centered hyper-dimensional “pseudo-atom” for each constituent structure, it enables the variability within the ensemble to be treated as displacements of this entity. This representation enables the direct application of standard tools such as covariance or community network analyses to access features such as correlated dynamics and allostery. The EVA approach was then combined with the unsupervised Mean Shift clustering algorithm to generate the EVA-MS approach for the analyses of protein structural ensembles.

This approach has now been applied to ascertain the "functional dynamics" of many ATP-processing enzymes inlcuding proteins kinases and ATPases.

Broader Impacts

This award allowed the comprehensive training of a graduate student in the design and implementation of cutting-edge computational approaches, their application to generate specific hypotheses and the experimental verfication of these hypotheses. Two undergraduates majoring in computer science were also given their first comprehensive exposure to modern computational structural biology.


Last Modified: 02/01/2022
Modified by: Ranajeet Ghose
